function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Ambiguous definition of 'nature' in architecture may lead to misunderstandings and debates about its effectiveness.","Impact":"Reduced trust in the ability of 'nature' in architecture to improve health, wellbeing, and resilience.","Mitigation":"Clearly define and articulate the concept of 'nature' in architecture, and engage in open dialogue to address differing perspectives.","Technologies":"Conceptual modeling tools, virtual reality simulations for visualizing design concepts.","People":"Architects, urban planners, building designers","Owner":"Architectural associations, professional organizations"},{"Description":"Literal greening used as a marketing tool may create false expectations and limited impact on social, economic, and environmental challenges.","Impact":"Disillusionment and skepticism towards the effectiveness of literal greening in addressing societal and environmental issues.","Mitigation":"Provide transparent and evidence-based information about the actual impacts of literal greening, and emphasize holistic approaches to sustainability.","Technologies":"Life cycle assessment tools, environmental impact assessment software","People":"Consumers, real estate developers, urban developers","Owner":"Sustainability organizations, environmental NGOs"},{"Description":"Inadequate consideration of disease transmission in natural design elements could pose a risk to public health in built environments.","Impact":"Increased susceptibility to contagious diseases due to poor design of 'natural' elements in built environments.","Mitigation":"Consult public health experts and epidemiologists in the design process to incorporate measures that minimize disease transmission","Technologies":"Airflow modeling software, disease transmission simulation tools","People":"Architects, public health experts, building occupants","Owner":"Architectural firms, public health agencies"}]}
